subject: Adding a healthcheck/status middleware.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

healthcheck is not intended to be a mod_status equivalent - it is intended to allow the client to check that the server is responding to requests. The idea is for it to be a short path through the HTTP request processing stack so that it will return 200 even if there is other stuff broken. That sounds like a perfect use case for HEAD to me.

If you want to propose the equivalent of mod_status, go for it - but healthcheck isn't it."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Duplicates https://review.openstack.org/11074 and blueprint port-swift-healthcheck

Conclusion I came to is that supporting HEAD on top-level entrypoints would be better

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-August/000614.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-September/001166.html'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Also, following inline with what other servers do, haproxy, a load balancer service itself has a statistics page (similar to the one this middleware is creating). http://code.google.com/p/haproxy-docs/wiki/StatisticsMonitoring so I think there is value in having some level of stats come out (and the more the better). The concept seems useful generally and to act as a response to said load balancers for 'health'."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

WIP'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ok, will rename it :-P'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

And another reason why following mod_status makes sense, if people are using http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_proxy_balancer.html (we aren't) then something that works like mod_status is what this module actually requires. I haven't messed around with either to much, but why try to change to HEAD, when GET seems to be the 'unoffical' standard, even if its not the best REST method?"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Interesting, that review was marked 'Status Abandoned' so that is why this one was opened. Why the HEAD choice? From what I understand, apache mod_status which is what everyone is used to is based on GET, so wouldn't that make more sense to follow? This is also similar to php's phpinfo() which is also typically via GET. Another consideration, since this is going to be hit by load balancers (its main purpose) how supported is HEAD in different balancers (I'm not sure actually but I would think GET is better supported).


Also HEAD requests can't return any body information, which seems like is actually pretty durn useful (especially if we can get more eventlet information out) so that sort of might make GET better?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/2/check/gate-openstack-common-merge/656 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/2/check/gate-openstack-common-pep8/524 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/2/check/gate-openstack-common-python26/523 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/2/check/gate-openstack-common-python27/523 : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress

Still WIP'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/3/check/gate-openstack-common-merge/657 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/3/check/gate-openstack-common-pep8/525 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/3/check/gate-openstack-common-python26/524 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/3/check/gate-openstack-common-python27/524 : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Work In Progress

Why u not set...'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/4/check/gate-openstack-common-merge/658 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/4/check/gate-openstack-common-pep8/526 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/4/check/gate-openstack-common-python26/525 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/4/check/gate-openstack-common-python27/525 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Is this something that belongs in openstack-common? Glance isn't going to need this code to function - operators should be able to get this through alternate means and add it to their paste file on an opt-in basis."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm always a little worried about adding new API functionality, because that means we're committing to it until the end of time. We can discuss how to integrate with specific projects later, though.

As for this review - I'd like to see the output be a single JSON object. I don't want to write any custom parsing for this.

I also want to hear what value you think there is in dumping the request env.

A HEAD response should never have content and should therefore use 204, not 200."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: No score

I'm just thinking out loud, I'm having trouble figuring out what I mean :/"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Sure, adding new api functionality though is one problem that is a little hard to predict (although I've tried a little) but I understand the desire/concern. Any ideas on what could be done better there now to start (or maybe its just a wait and see game...). 

JSON is fine for me for the extended 'details' (the request environ may not be useful, just was a thought). I think we also want a mode that returns 'OK' as well (since some load balancers want that it seems + swift) when a GET request (no details configured is asked for) and the HEAD request can do as u said. Will update for that."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I thought the goal of openstack-common was not to be code that everyone requires to function but common code that everyone can use if they choose... Useful stuff that avoids duplication (DRY) was i thought the idea of this whole project?'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

No worries, thats what this is here for :-P'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/5/check/gate-openstack-common-merge/677 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/5/check/gate-openstack-common-pep8/545 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/5/check/gate-openstack-common-python26/544 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/5/check/gate-openstack-common-python27/544 : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/6/check/gate-openstack-common-merge/678 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/6/check/gate-openstack-common-pep8/546 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/6/check/gate-openstack-common-python26/545 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/12759/6/check/gate-openstack-common-python27/545 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I don't think there's any need to add "might be useful to someone" middlewares to openstack-common - you could very well release such middlewares completely independently

It really only makes sense in openstack-common if the projects actively want to include it'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I think the approach should be to first get buy-in from each of the API owners - i.e. that at least some of the services would include this in their API pipelines'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

So any thoughts on getting this in?'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Ready For Review

Seems to be ok now.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Understood, maybe this should go in a separate pypi 'wsgi_status' or something along that lines."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Ok, let me start a public thread on this. If not when common becomes a actual library (i think thats in grizzly) this could just be something useful that people add into there own pipelines. Is that planned for grizzly to do that?'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-20 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

Eventually, both XML and JSON will be supported, but for now make the
output JSON, the same as the input.

Change-Id: If0f00b182c27616a9a6f08b468d732c718b7635a
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Start and enable libvirtd.

Just did a fresh install on fedora 17 and found libvirt was not running
by default which caused nova to not start.  Explicitly enable it.

Change-Id: Id244af934007020d1a9f263dd71f04e5950dd2c5
Signed-off-by: Ian Main <imain@redhat.com>

commit_message:
heat engine : remove unused EC2 style auth from engine

We handle EC2 style auth at the heat-api-cfn level, so EC2
style authenticated requests simply pass us an auth_token in
the context, so remove this duplicate/dead code.

Ref #268

Change-Id: I17708cb6ef4b0eb4989d47c116b6211f0d419dcb
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

-        time.sleep(0.15)  # avoid occasional "Address already in use"?
 
     def statsd_reader(self):
         while True:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-15 18:38:10.000000000', 'message': "Make StatsD tests less flaky.

There have been a bunch of Jenkins failures lately where the StatsD
tests fail because they can't bind to their desired port. There's
nothing special about the particular port they're using, so in case of
EADDRINUSE, the test will now just try the next port up.

If every port is bound, then eventually the test will try to
.bind(('localhost', 65536)), and that will raise a different error, so
the test won't search forever.

This also lets us get rid of a sleep() in the test that looked like an
attempt to alleviate EADDRINUSE errors, so now in the happy case, the
tests are a few fractions of a second faster.

Change-Id: Idee11349254107a59643539b1566f3588eee7ef4
"}, {'created': '2012-10-16 18:21:06.000000000', 'message': "Make StatsD tests less flaky.

There have been a bunch of Jenkins failures lately where the StatsD
tests fail because they can't bind to their desired port. There's
nothing special about the particular port they're using, so now we let
the kernel pick an available one for us.

This also lets us get rid of a sleep() in the test that looked like an
attempt to alleviate EADDRINUSE errors, so now in the happy case, the
tests are a few fractions of a second faster.

Change-Id: Idee11349254107a59643539b1566f3588eee7ef4
"}]
commit_message:
Make StatsD tests less flaky.

There have been a bunch of Jenkins failures lately where the StatsD
tests fail because they can't bind to their desired port. There's
nothing special about the particular port they're using, so now we let
the kernel pick an available one for us.

This also lets us get rid of a sleep() in the test that looked like an
attempt to alleviate EADDRINUSE errors, so now in the happy case, the
tests are a few fractions of a second faster.

Change-Id: Idee11349254107a59643539b1566f3588eee7ef4

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-19 00:54:43.000000000', 'message': "Remove replication prioritization

Turns out this prioritization causes stampedes right after capacity
additions (especially on smaller clusters), which means the things it
prioritizes don't get done for several passes anyway, which means the
prioritization isn't solving the problem it was designed to do, and
it causes non-productive load spikes instead. :/

Getting rid of the prioritization doesn't make things go any slower
overall, could make things actually go faster since there are less
collisions, and evens out the load.

Change-Id: I4938bcd12d9a21fad635cfe772897e4c151f8a95
"}]
commit_message:
Remove replication prioritization

Turns out this prioritization causes stampedes right after capacity
additions (especially on smaller clusters), which means the things it
prioritizes don't get done for several passes anyway, which means the
prioritization isn't solving the problem it was designed to do, and
it causes non-productive load spikes instead. :/

Getting rid of the prioritization doesn't make things go any slower
overall, could make things actually go faster since there are less
collisions, and evens out the load.

Change-Id: I4938bcd12d9a21fad635cfe772897e4c151f8a95

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-18 04:05:31.000000000', 'message': 'Relax mount point name checking.

In general, Linux does not care about what a mount point is named as
long as it is a vaild directory name (no / or null characters).
However, that is too relaxed for swift, which will pass that mount
point name around as part of url path construction all over the
place.  To make sure that the mount point name was sane from that POV,
Swift was using isalnum to verify that the mount point name was sane,
which is overly restrictive.

This patch replaces that test with a test that verifies that the name
has no characters that need to be URL encoded.

The specific use case this enables is allowing mount points to be
named according to the UUID of the filesystem that is being mounted,
which will make Swift more robust in the face of device name instability.

Change-Id: I4d49b21c1783e97c16d3f394c2171f1f80eea058
'}, {'created': '2012-10-18 16:24:20.000000000', 'message': 'Relax mount point name checking.

In general, Linux does not care about what a mount point is named as
long as it is a vaild directory name (no / or null characters).
However, that is too relaxed for swift, which will pass that mount
point name around as part of url path construction all over the
place.  To make sure that the mount point name was sane from that POV,
Swift was using isalnum to verify that the mount point name was sane,
which is overly restrictive.

This patch replaces that test with a test that verifies that the name
has no characters that need to be URL encoded.

The specific use case this enables is allowing mount points to be
named according to the UUID of the filesystem that is being mounted,
which will make Swift more robust in the face of device name instability.

Change-Id: I4d49b21c1783e97c16d3f394c2171f1f80eea058
'}]
commit_message:
Relax mount point name checking.

In general, Linux does not care about what a mount point is named as
long as it is a vaild directory name (no / or null characters).
However, that is too relaxed for swift, which will pass that mount
point name around as part of url path construction all over the
place.  To make sure that the mount point name was sane from that POV,
Swift was using isalnum to verify that the mount point name was sane,
which is overly restrictive.

This patch replaces that test with a test that verifies that the name
has no characters that need to be URL encoded.

The specific use case this enables is allowing mount points to be
named according to the UUID of the filesystem that is being mounted,
which will make Swift more robust in the face of device name instability.

Change-Id: I4d49b21c1783e97c16d3f394c2171f1f80eea058

Tenant names may come and go, but UUIDs are universally unique. Therefore,
ownership of the stack should be keyed on the tenant_id, not the tenant
name.

Change-Id: I7ec410aeaeceb6319299935b5f34d7c4e9c63d67
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Identify stacks using tenant UUIDs

Tenant names may come and go, but UUIDs are universally unique. Therefore,
ownership of the stack should be keyed on the tenant_id, not the tenant
name.

Change-Id: I7ec410aeaeceb6319299935b5f34d7c4e9c63d67
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2012-10-19 06:03:04.000000000', 'message': 'Support RabbitMQ H/A cancellation notifications.

Upgrading to newer kombu and pyamqp transport to make
use of newer kombu's support for RabbitMQ cancellation
notifications, which happen when a consumer is consuming
from a replica of a queue and the queue's master dies.

See http://www.rabbitmq.com/ha.html "Mirrored Queue Behavior".

With older kombu, in this case the consumer just never
gets any more messages even if the master recovers or if
messages are published to other replicas of the queue.

With new kombu, the consumer will get a ConsumerCancel
exception in connection.drain_events when this happens.

Newer kombu requires newer anyjson - see
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-common/+bug/1031889

Alas, this change can only be tested manually so far.

commit_message:
Support RabbitMQ H/A cancellation notifications.

Upgrading to newer kombu and pyamqp transport to make
use of newer kombu's support for RabbitMQ cancellation
notifications, which happen when a consumer is consuming
from a replica of a queue and the queue's master dies.

See http://www.rabbitmq.com/ha.html "Mirrored Queue Behavior".

With older kombu, in this case the consumer just never
gets any more messages even if the master recovers or if
messages are published to other replicas of the queue.

With new kombu, the consumer will get a ConsumerCancel
exception in connection.drain_events when this happens.

Newer kombu requires newer anyjson - see
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-common/+bug/1031889

Alas, this change can only be tested manually so far.

Change-Id: I8242a33e0f9925feb0a6c3bf1d3f87832b8ceb8b

* with StrOpt('foo', positional=True, ...),
  positional parameter will make a positional
  argument, whose command line value could be
  retreived later by reading attribute from
  ConfigOpts object, such as cfg.foo or
  cfg['foo']
* positional arguments are in sequential order,
  the same order as they are registered.

Change-Id: I51381c80ccb32bdf6ac7fada30b4c991871416c8
"}]
commit_message:
positional argument support

* with StrOpt('foo', positional=True, ...),
  positional parameter will make a positional
  argument, whose command line value could be
  retreived later by reading attribute from
  ConfigOpts object, such as cfg.foo or
  cfg['foo']
* positional arguments are in sequential order,
  the same order as they are registered.

Change-Id: I51381c80ccb32bdf6ac7fada30b4c991871416c8

Laurence - I'm having difficult understanding the use case for this

e.g. if I take your test case and do this:

      def test_multi_name_option(self):
          self.conf.register_cli_opt(StrOpt('foo'))
 -        self.conf.register_cli_opt(StrOpt('foo-bar'))
 -        self.conf.register_cli_opt(StrOpt('foo_bar'))
 +        self.conf.register_cli_opt(StrOpt('foo-bar',
 +                                          deprecated_name='foo_bar'))
          args = ['--foo', 'blaa', '--foo-bar', 'blaa', '--foo_bar', 'blaa']
 
          self.conf(args)
 
          self.assertEquals(self.conf.foo, 'blaa')
 -        self.assertEquals(self.conf['foo-bar'], 'blaa')
 +        self.assertEquals(self.conf['foo_bar'], 'blaa')
          self.assertEquals(self.conf.foo_bar, 'blaa')

then it works just fine

Am I missing something?"}, {'account_id': 5727, 'date': '2012-10-19 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5727, 'date': '2012-10-19 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Firstly, the test cases are wrong, sorry for that.
Secondly, this idea is from a practice of some in use openstack client, that is using more than 2-3 names(2 of them are deprecated) for a option for compatibility, and apparently, current cfg module could not support that.

Anyway, allow me try to finish the argparse bigger issue, then come back to this topic.

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-19 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

commit_message:
multi-name for single option

 example:
 * --foo-bar, --foo_bar and --foobar can be assigned
 * to the same dest 'foo-bar', so that deprecated
 * options can exists with new options till the later
 * ones got flourished.

Change-Id: I377cef0613da6b6a501c1714a6187b49a6cde90f

subject: Add a way to map package names from one distro to another
messages:
[{'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-10-04 14:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Three things to note:

- this patch requires bash 4. It's been released a while ago, so I don't think it's an issue.

- this version of the patch actually depends on the preliminary openSUSE support. I can change this if needed. It just happened that my branches were setup like this.

- if no package map exists for a vendor, then we simply use the original package lists. This means that with this patch and no package map, there's actually no change in the behavior."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-04 14:20:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-04 14:00:22.000000000', 'message': "Add a way to map package names from one distro to another

To support different distributions, we currently list packages needed
for each distribution. This is not fun, especially as most package names
are common. Also, to properly support this in all the code, we need to
add several if/elif/else/fi.

Instead, we can use a map to match the package names from one distro
(that we'll consider as a basis, with package names used in the code) to
the package names of another distribution. This means we simply need to
add a file containing the mapping to support this other distribution --
at least, in terms of packaging.

Mapping files are in files/package-maps/ and are named after the
vendors. Format is the following:

 a) To map a single package to one or more packages:
      original_name first_package,second_package
 b) To keep the same name for the mapping, just put:
      original_name
    (or alternatively, do not even put the file in the mapping, but we
    might add tests to make sure there's a mapping defined for each
    package)
 c) To accomodate a package not existing in the target distro, use:
      original_name -
    This will simply skip this package for the target distro.

Change-Id: I01b29ec73a7294f11d74adcf2c9a62797d88383c
"}]
commit_message:
Add a way to map package names from one distro to another

To support different distributions, we currently list packages needed
for each distribution. This is not fun, especially as most package names
are common. Also, to properly support this in all the code, we need to
add several if/elif/else/fi.

Instead, we can use a map to match the package names from one distro
(that we'll consider as a basis, with package names used in the code) to
the package names of another distribution. This means we simply need to
add a file containing the mapping to support this other distribution --
at least, in terms of packaging.

Mapping files are in files/package-maps/ and are named after the
vendors. Format is the following:

 a) To map a single package to one or more packages:
      original_name first_package,second_package
 b) To keep the same name for the mapping, just put:
      original_name
    (or alternatively, do not even put the file in the mapping, but we
    might add tests to make sure there's a mapping defined for each
    package)
 c) To accomodate a package not existing in the target distro, use:
      original_name -
    This will simply skip this package for the target distro.

Change-Id: I01b29ec73a7294f11d74adcf2c9a62797d88383c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-14 00:44:58.000000000', 'message': 'Fix fragile respawn storm test

This test was fragile in part because it was using an awkward and
imprecise shell command to find the glance api worker processes. This
change modifies the query to specifically target the children of the api
process under test.

Fixes bug 1049408

Change-Id: Ia67dd42c3f3f6970075d046d9fc8623c736ae4a6
'}]
commit_message:
Fix fragile respawn storm test

This test was fragile in part because it was using an awkward and
imprecise shell command to find the glance api worker processes. This
change modifies the query to specifically target the children of the api
process under test.

Fixes bug 1049408

Change-Id: Ia67dd42c3f3f6970075d046d9fc8623c736ae4a6

Nice one Michael

Agree with Jason's comment on copying the test over

We're trying to avoid adding new code to utils.py but rather adding more fine-grained utils modules so projects can choose which ones they import. Also, this allows us to release the utils in different library releases when we get to that point.

How about lockutils.py for this?

I've a bunch of comments inline, but the one's which definitely need fixing are the FLAGS stuff and the 'nova-' prefix

Also, the cleanup_dir stuff looks really suspicious to me"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-10-18 18:02:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I've addressed most of your concerns. I'm trying hard to avoid the temptation to change this code during the port... I ended up here because there is stuff I want to change here too, but I figured we should move it into common first.

I'd like this review to be as close to a straight port as possible. I agree there are things which need to be fixed, but I'd like to see those in a later review to make this less confusing to later readers.

I'm also not sure how concerned we should be with the native threading issues in this code, given we don't use native threads."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-18 18:02:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Move nova's util.synchronized decorator to openstack common.

In the end I needed to port utils.ensure_tree as well. Resolves
bug 1063230.

Change-Id: I6e6fa8201de2cac3f17e6c60d7b16f7df7c64116

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-18 16:49:50.000000000', 'message': 'heat engine : Make wait-condition poll interval better

Remove rising-rate sleep-time logic and replace with a bounded
poll interval derived from the timeout - this should avoid ramping
up to a really long interval and delaying stack complete status

Fixes #264

Change-Id: Id53b87a988299708c29fc853f2801f527fd825dd
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
heat engine : Make wait-condition poll interval better

Remove rising-rate sleep-time logic and replace with a bounded
poll interval derived from the timeout - this should avoid ramping
up to a really long interval and delaying stack complete status

Fixes #264

Change-Id: Id53b87a988299708c29fc853f2801f527fd825dd
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

WAYYYY early prototype work'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-03 19:21:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

- http://logs.openstack.org/14001/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/1385 : FAILURE (non-voting)
"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-10-03 19:31:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I understand this is an early prototype, but I'm scratching head after reading the original bug and the blueprint.

This just moves database access from direct access to indirect access. Instead of an attacker connecting directly to the database, now they send a message to a queue to do the same thing.

It seems like this is a lot of complexity for very little benefit.

I'm guessing at the motivation behind this service since the blueprint doesn't explain why we want this."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-10-03 19:44:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

My understanding has always been that the RPC channel is considered privileged (I've asked this several times). I think  that most of the RPC interfaces in other services make this assumption and thus provide plenty of opportunity for an attacker who has gained access to it. No?

If this is not the case, then I think that there is a reasonable amount of policy-checking that could be done in nova-sync to ensure access only to data pertinent to your credentials. However, it's still a clear security win for the nodes to lose all direct database access and to force would-be attackers through small API holes, right?

I think there are a number of concrete goals of no-db-compute, some of which are about security and some of which are about scalability and performance."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-10-03 20:39:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure what privileged means in that context, but nova.conf has the username, password and host for the RPC connection as well.

If the concern is that someone can get the SQL connection information, they have exact same information for the RPC connection.

It would be just slightly more work to send a message to this nova-sink service to update the database than do it directly with the database.

Also, our RPC communications don't provide any authentication of the sender. If we're moving instance_update() to a new service, it would need to allow updates to any instance from any service (compute or not).

I guess there might be a small increase in security by preventing access to the parts of the database that isn't implemented by the service, but I'm hesitant to say the small increase in security is worth the increased complexity here."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-10-06 17:19:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Well, if the DBA has sufficiently locked down the database user that the compute service uses to do instance updates, then there's not much to be gained there, I'll agree. If, however, the compute nodes use a general user with full access to nova.*, then I think this still creates a smaller hole through which accesses may be done.

Security aside, I think there are still other reasons backing the desire to strip database accesses from the compute nodes, such as removing the service heartbeat rendezvous, improving live upgradability, etc.

I'll let originator(s) of the blueprint (i.e. Russell) speak up here, or perhaps we should continue discussion at the summit session for this :)"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-10-06 17:23:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Oops, I meant to say above:

It's entirely possible that Russell had a more fine-grained approach in mind to this service, which would replace instance_update() with actual RPC-API calls for individual things. I'm not sure that buys us anything for a supposedly-trusted interface, other than potential for API churn and other issues. Hence my punting to him for comments."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-10-10 11:02:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think we need to do some design documentation and post that to openstack-dev and have this discussion there.  Gerrit isn't a great place for design discussion."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-10-10 18:17:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

Actually, there is a session for this next week.  Let's hold the discussion until then.  We can go into it in detail in the session and summarize it on the list afterwards.  Then we can come back to this after that shakes out."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-18 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-18 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

[{'created': '2012-10-03 18:51:57.000000000', 'message': 'Way-early prototype nova-sink service

This adds a new service called "nova-sink" which serves to complete
database updates on behalf of other services (such as nova-compute)
which endeavor to avoid such things.

This is just enough code at this point to actually run and pass
tests. There is a lot of work to be done, methods to add, etc.
However, this provides instance_update() which seems to be the

commit_message:
Way-early prototype nova-sink service

This adds a new service called "nova-sink" which serves to complete
database updates on behalf of other services (such as nova-compute)
which endeavor to avoid such things.

This is just enough code at this point to actually run and pass
tests. There is a lot of work to be done, methods to add, etc.
However, this provides instance_update() which seems to be the
most obvious thing to snag first from nova-compute.

Change-Id: I97e55b19fd6e72c48c3009cb2678d7b6f30f7dc7

commit_message:
Fix bug 1064749 - KVM module load order may mean you need to
change the privileges.

Added to KVM troubleshooting - alternatively we could rearrange
the order of the entire book so that the installation goes with
defaults, then discusses hypervisor setup.

Adds a note to the top of the KVM section to indicate you should
not load the module prior to installing the nova-compute service.

Change-Id: Ib88dcd595518214d7c6c626578dec808affde002

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-17 18:57:45.000000000', 'message': "Ensure JSON isn't read on no  HTTP response body

This patch moves the json.loads(body) call in the
HTTP response handling to after the check for non-
200-300 return codes. This gets rid of the
ValueError exception raise when you hit, for instance,
a 400 or 404.

Also changes a number of logger.exception() calls to
logger.debug() calls, since some exceptions are expected
and should not be logged as exceptions per-se.

fixes LP bug#1067512

Change-Id: If66fb1846ddc19da5bc2f15c6e0dd09019a56932
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure JSON isn't read on no  HTTP response body

This patch moves the json.loads(body) call in the
HTTP response handling to after the check for non-
200-300 return codes. This gets rid of the
ValueError exception raise when you hit, for instance,
a 400 or 404.

Also changes a number of logger.exception() calls to
logger.debug() calls, since some exceptions are expected
and should not be logged as exceptions per-se.

fixes LP bug#1067512

Change-Id: If66fb1846ddc19da5bc2f15c6e0dd09019a56932

commit_message:
Use consoleauth rpcapi in nova-novncproxy.

The nova-novncproxy service was using rpc.call directly when it should
have been going through the rpcapi client proxy class.  This patch fixes
that.

Fix bug 1067858.

Change-Id: I626fb01ff61ff507520d528122358ef687d297b7

'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-10-17 17:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-17 17:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/14401/3/check/gate-openstack-common-merge/826 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14401/3/check/gate-openstack-common-pep8/694 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/14401/3/check/gate-openstack-common-python27/693 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-10-17 17:23:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

What worries me about this is that it seems to effectively turn *every* function into the codebase into an API that may be consumed by out-of-tree code to some degree.  It may not be calling this code, but it is depending on the current implementation and set of functions that exist.

I think I'd much rather see specific notifications/hooks/whatever explicitly added where they make sense in a way that is decoupled from the current implementation details."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-10-17 17:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-10-17 17:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> but it is depending on the current implementation and 
> set of functions that exis

That concerns me as well.

On the other hand, I just now had the experience of needing to know when something was happening in Nova (a particular metadata change) and had no way of learning about it short of live-patching my production cluster or adding a notification to the code and waiting six months.

So... I'm convinced that we need a way to allow third-party code to dig into internals, even if they aren't officially versioned.  The counterpart to this is that we will also need a mechanism for plugins to announce something like "I am coded for Nova version 2012.3" and be rejected by other versions.

I'd be happy to move this function into plugin-support files if that seems more appropriate.

Also, this is one of the main topics I want to bring up this week; planning to discuss at 'entrypoint based plugins' 11:00 Wednesday.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-10-17 17:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2012-10-17 17:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Looks fine except for a whitespace nit.'}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2012-10-17 17:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-10-17 17:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

I am now convinced that this is a bad idea :)'}]

commit_message:
Support adding arbitrary notifications at runtime.

This will allow plugins to request notification of
function calls that don't ordinarly send notifications.

For blueprint novaplugins

Change-Id: If9af33a8d4677903385d12b0076032b2cfec0a1d

[{'created': '2012-10-17 16:49:41.000000000', 'message': "Fix a couple of file handle leaks, using with statements.

In practice unclosed file handle leaks are not a huge deal in CPython code,
because reference counting means they get closed automatically in a timely
manner.  But they're bad style, and they can become a real problem if the
code is run with a version of Python that doesn't use reference counting.

Change-Id: Ie54b979e26ffc9dd405871ee07c50b304cb36c67
"}]
commit_message:
Fix a couple of file handle leaks, using with statements.

In practice unclosed file handle leaks are not a huge deal in CPython code,
because reference counting means they get closed automatically in a timely
manner.  But they're bad style, and they can become a real problem if the
code is run with a version of Python that doesn't use reference counting.

Change-Id: Ie54b979e26ffc9dd405871ee07c50b304cb36c67

(4 inline comments)

The idea of using constants instead of hardcoding the same strings everywhere is great.

I don't like the first line of the commit message, because it requires looking in the bug tracker to see what the commit actually does.  And it only autolinks the first bug not the second.

I marked a few spots with non-PEP8-compliant indentation.  You need to align the argument on the continuation line with the argument on the first line, rather than just indenting it 4 spaces, so that it's clearly a continuation rather than an indented block."}, {'account_id': 4912, 'date': '2012-10-17 16:25:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2012-10-17 16:25:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Fix Bug #1057831 and 1061628.

This patch tries to take care of anywhere in the code that
is hardcoded to use binary topics like 'volume' or 'compute'.
Instead we should be using FLAGS.volume_topic, etc.

Change-Id: I6a9422b650e4f33cc830b285dda2dac8bbe63195

commit_message:
Handle upgrades in heat-keystone-setup

Handle upgrades of Heat by removing any outdated endpoints that exist in
keystone and adding any existing "heat" service user to an admin role in
the service tenant.

Change-Id: If6393417b5404a56b4723f42fb1a1b394d01cc6a
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

Rename CloudFormation service to heat-cfn

This is consistent with what is implemented in devstack.

Change-Id: If47c28ddbef1d6c61e2d741f359d850e4ecffaa9
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
heat tests : Remove utils.Stack getter methods

Remove the get_*_client getter methods, as they aren't
actually doing anything, so just access the attributes

Change-Id: Ic6740bdfe7d44c40b9fdf9fc4d03f8eddaf9a740
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-17 08:28:55.000000000', 'message': 'Use password in preference to token if both supplied

Fixes #263 - devstack is providing a token in the environment, which was
causing the wrong path to get hit.

Change-Id: I9aae346e57fdfe156e52d4696e8f2f859884ff2f
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Use password in preference to token if both supplied

Fixes #263 - devstack is providing a token in the environment, which was
causing the wrong path to get hit.

Change-Id: I9aae346e57fdfe156e52d4696e8f2f859884ff2f
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Updates the Networking chapter in the Compute Admin Guide

Ensures that it is clear that the chapter is for nova-network, not
Quantum.

Change-Id: I2e650a2ee36818760a5132b1a9118a0698db9e4a

Handle invalid xml request to return BadRequest

Handled ExpatError,LookupError to return BadRequest
if the user inputs the invalid xml

fixes bug 1032092

Change-Id: I7374532d91e3d7675bc80730031a195f50bb2abc

commit_message:
Random pep8 fixes!

This patch merely fixes a selection of files to the point where
pep8 1.3.3 is happy. Most of the errors are indentation related to
continued lines (E126, E127, E128), bracket positions (E124) and the
use of backslash (E502).

Patch 2 fixes David's comments regarding backslash and an odd comment
 - thanks David!

Change-Id: I4fbd77ecf5395743cb96acb95fa946c322c16560

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-15 16:12:01.000000000', 'message': "Fail to assign fixed ips

Fixes bug 1065004.

If using multi host configuration, with FilterScheduler and
FlatDHCPManager, the dhcp server is not configured properly, because at
the time network_get_associated_fixed_ips is called, instance's host
field is not set since change 5fd7a9dba127bae812333196a5fa48a933212aeb .
This change modifies the query, so the filtering is done on the fixed
ip's host field. The host field is set during allocate_fixed_ip.

Change-Id: I992bbdc69aeae1b5afa9b5a7ff4a60ba6202500c
"}]
commit_message:
Fail to assign fixed ips

Fixes bug 1065004.

If using multi host configuration, with FilterScheduler and
FlatDHCPManager, the dhcp server is not configured properly, because at
the time network_get_associated_fixed_ips is called, instance's host
field is not set since change 5fd7a9dba127bae812333196a5fa48a933212aeb .
This change modifies the query, so the filtering is done on the fixed
ip's host field. The host field is set during allocate_fixed_ip.

Change-Id: I992bbdc69aeae1b5afa9b5a7ff4a60ba6202500c

commit_message:
Set instance host field after resource claim

Set the 'host' field on the instance after the resource tracker
on the compute node has accepted the build.

The field is set after resources are confirmed to be available while the
COMPUTE_RESOURCES_SEMAPHORE is held.  The semaphore ensures the
resources usage values will be consistent even if the
update_available_resource periodic task audit runs.

bug 1060255

Change-Id: I92105ec14924960ac8ef7ca8c810783085314e10

commit_message:
Remove db access for block devices and network info on reboot

This makes compute/api pass the block device and network info to
compute_manager::reboot_instance() so that it doesn't have to hit
the database itself.

This also extends the reboot tests for the compute manager and
api to validate that these two bits of data are making it all the
way through the stack.

bp no-db-compute

Change-Id: I92346d6c821241885b5f4b08fec05f38e6261edf

commit_message:
Remove db access for block devices on terminate_instance

This makes compute/api pass in an instance's block devices to
compute/manager::terminate_instance() so that it doesn't have
to hit the database itself.

Note that this doesn't remove all database activity in the
terminate_instance() path, just the block-device-related bits.

bp no-db-compute

Change-Id: Ibfb333ef7918e05f0e3634f1fb063f1b02535bff

commit_message:
add a new HTTPClient attr for setting the original IP

The original IP is useful in cases where keystoneclient is used by a
different openstack component and we need to know who made the original
request. Otherwise it gets overwritten by e.g. Dashboard's host's IP.

bug 1046837

Change-Id: I803fe9759b073fa1bc3d65240962a51f610db9d1

commit_message:
add a new HTTPClient attr for setting the original IP

The original IP is useful in cases where keystoneclient is used by a
different openstack component and we need to know who made the original
request. Otherwise it gets overwritten by e.g. Dashboard's host's IP.

bug 1046837

Change-Id: I438616a582895a7fff889084b661787cc03cf32f

commit_message:
Revert "fanout subscriptions in impl_zmq"

This changed the message format without consideration
for versioning. If this is resubmitted, it will be
only after message versioning is introduced.

This reverts commit 032bf345ea593e97fcc07e23c1725ba5f4b612d0.

Change-Id: I4f4326b0ba78699b5f149cc2d2822235e9a30462

[{'created': '2012-10-16 14:46:57.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Support declare_topic_consumer in impl_zmq"

Depends on reverted patch. Not used by any code or project.
This was an implementation of an internal AMQP-driver method.

commit_message:
Revert "Support declare_topic_consumer in impl_zmq"

Depends on reverted patch. Not used by any code or project.
This was an implementation of an internal AMQP-driver method.

Will determine long-term requirement or replacement
for declare_topic_consumer at Grizzly sumit.

This reverts commit d5095d7effe79c1dcf19a67ff03e00a454662830.

Change-Id: I48883c5011ebccba3e6f987ae48bff871d016bd1

subject: xenapi: Check size of VHDs before snapshot upload.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 616, 'name': 'Mark Washenberger', 'email': 'mark.washenberger@markwash.net', 'username': 'markwash'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2537, 'name': 'Nikhil Komawar', 'email': 'nik.komawar@gmail.com', 'username': 'nikhil-komawar'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-10-04 20:42:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is there a blueprint for this?'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-10-04 20:47:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-04 21:26:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/14062/1/check/gate-nova-merge/9748 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14062/1/check/gate-nova-docs/5503 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14062/1/check/gate-nova-pep8/10813 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14062/1/check/gate-nova-python26/6958 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14062/1/check/gate-nova-python27/7023 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14062/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/13709 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14062/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-cinder/3688 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14062/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/1449 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-10-05 17:28:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Johannes: No blueprint, this was originally from a V1 tix.

Personally, I wouldn't classify this as a big enough change to merit a full BP. It's really just a sanity check, not too different from capping the number of seeder processes in a dom0."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-10-05 17:50:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I haven't seen a reason for this feature in trunk. Nova doesn't care what the size of the snapshot is, and it's certainly not unbounded, it's limited by the largest instance type.

I've heard other reasons why this might be useful in our case (Rackspace), but even those reasons seem like a hack.

I do have a reason why this shouldn't be applied, and that is that I don't think people will understand why it fails when it does. It depends on the size of the VHD when that can vary wildly depending on how the instance is being used. From a user experience standpoint, it'll end causing some confusion.

Ultimately it seems like we're trying to solve a problem that trunk doesn't have.

So that's why I'm looking for a blueprint, to understand the rationale for it."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-10-05 20:29:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Ultimately it seems like we're trying to solve a problem that trunk doesn't have.

Trunk doesn't have incremental backup support, so, I'd argue that it *very* much does have this problem.

True it's 'bounded'in a strict sense by the instance-type size, but when the business-reality[1] of having to support large instance types meets the engineering-reality of having to move X number of bits across a wire, something has to give.

We can either fail ungracefully by having large backups and snapshots timeout in an unpredictable manner, or we can place a hard upper-bound on it and have it fail in a (mostly)[2] predictable way.

[1] I doubt very much that Rackspace is the only one offering large enough instance-types that backups will be troublesome until an incremental backup solution is found. To that extent, I think having this trunk means at least everyone is aware of the problem and have a (admittedly somewhat hackish) workaround.

[2] You're right that VHD size is not a perfect metric here but, at the moment, it's the best we've got :)"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-10-05 20:37:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

There's an assumption here that backups and snapshots do timeout. I haven't seen that, but I haven't looked for it either.

I haven't seen what the trouble is yet, which is why I'm asking for a blueprint!

I know that if you have backups scheduled to occur once a day and it takes longer than a day to snapshot and push up to glance you'll have some interesting problems, but that seems like a policy decision that is out of scope for nova."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-10-05 21:18:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> There's an assumption here that backups and snapshots do timeout. I haven't seen that, but I haven't looked for it either.

A 30 GB instance has 1.2 TB disk available yielding:

Data Uploaded 1.2 TB = 10555311626649.60 bits
10 Mbps: 279.62 hours
100 Mbps: 27.96 hours
1 Gbps: 2.73 hours

Sure these are worst case numbers, but they show we have some serious technical limitations here. Even incremental won't solve this because we still have to upload a full-backup every so often (unless we can manage to somehow perform coalesce operations in Swift directly).


> I haven't seen what the trouble is yet, which is why I'm asking for a blueprint!

I'll partially agree here. Having a blueprint is not a bad thing, but if we agree that this is a problem, then there are only so many ways to solve it, so being able to look at the actual proposed patch is a Good Thing.

So we could just use this patch as a point of discussion and put any pro/con arguments right here in the comments.

> I know that if you have backups scheduled to occur once a day and it takes longer than a day to snapshot and push up to glance you'll have some interesting problems, but that seems like a policy decision that is out of scope for nova.

I *love* pushing policy decisions outside of Nova, definitely a good thing for everyone.  That said, a check like this is highly coupled to underlying representations of the image and, for efficiency, require the check to be executed deep within the actual upload call.

I'm not sure how we have a check like this with a separate policy engine without a vastly different system of notifications and deep-hooks. That makes a solution impractical in the short/medium term (or likely, ever!)."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-10-05 21:44:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So it takes a long time for huge images to backup, but they still complete, right? Where's the timeout?

I'm still looking for the problem this patch is trying to solve.

In the worst case, all this patch does is confuse users. They could backup/snapshot their instance when it was new but now that they've used it for a while, they can't do a backup/snapshot anymore."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-10-05 22:25:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> So it takes a long time for huge images to backup, but they still complete, right? Where's the timeout?

Experience tells us they won't for a variety of reasons. With enough retry-logic can/should work through those, but an even more basic problem exists...

> I'm still looking for the problem this patch is trying to solve.

If a backup takes 8 hours to complete, do we even want to attempt it?

The decision we've made in the past is, 'no', because it's just not worth it. It ties up resources on the machine (disk I/O which seriously impacts customer experience) and on the network making other backups more likely to fail.

It's a scare-resource-optimization problem, and we've opted to maximize the number of succeeding backups at the expense of preemptively killing a (hopefully small) number of outlier backups.


All that said, there's a reasonable argument to be made that we hold off on merging this to trunk until more people express a need for it.

I'm fine w/ that, even though it means we have to hold on to this patch potentially indefinitely."}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2012-10-05 23:03:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

should the api not be empowered to handle the exception too?'}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2012-10-06 01:59:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

nvm'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-10-08 21:46:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So the implementation looks sound, and speaking from experience, I agree with Rick: we used to see this all the time. However, since it isn't really a bug, per say, I would agree with a blueprint at minimum."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-16 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-16 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-04 20:40:24.000000000', 'message': 'xenapi: Check size of VHDs before snapshot upload.

Validate that the pre-compression size of the image is under a specified
threshold before uploading to Glance.

Change-Id: I6b4f95f7e23d80aeeecb01194a81f3ee831eca59
'}]
commit_message:
xenapi: Check size of VHDs before snapshot upload.

Validate that the pre-compression size of the image is under a specified
threshold before uploading to Glance.

Change-Id: I6b4f95f7e23d80aeeecb01194a81f3ee831eca59

commit_message:
heat engine : remove unused validate_template params

Remove unused params argument to validate_template, since
it is no longer passed by the CFN API meaning the validate
action fails

Fixes #262

Change-Id: Ic2a5ede02649f2d6dff86595efb0127e07fbf253
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Reduce timeout periods in functional tests

Many of the timeouts were absurdly long and delayed reporting of test
results by many hours at a time.

Change-Id: I9a70442548097d607eab87471a8037b566127ac9
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-15 10:04:36.000000000', 'message': 'Getting Started: Fix IP address determination on F17

The format of the output of ifconfig has changed between Fedora 16 and
Fedora 17, so starting the metadata server failed on the latter due to a
missing IP address.

The change makes the script work with either format, and also now fails
with an error if it breaks again.

Change-Id: I7012af7bd7c15f6a962d19e66c8a0d8401243895
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Getting Started: Fix IP address determination on F17

The format of the output of ifconfig has changed between Fedora 16 and
Fedora 17, so starting the metadata server failed on the latter due to a
missing IP address.

The change makes the script work with either format, and also now fails
with an error if it breaks again.

Change-Id: I7012af7bd7c15f6a962d19e66c8a0d8401243895
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2012-10-15 08:57:11.000000000', 'message': 'heat : Remove cloudwatch functionalty from metadata server

Remove the cloudwatch metric functionality from the heat-metadata
service, since all stats should now be sent via the CloudWatch
api via the PutMetricData action (ref cfn-push-stats update)

Note that after this change you will need to rebuild your jeos
images to get the new version of cfn-push-stats from heat-jeos

Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5eec60d3dd0abfb32e2b4777635f1b0e2714a2c2
'}]
commit_message:
heat : Remove cloudwatch functionalty from metadata server

Remove the cloudwatch metric functionality from the heat-metadata
service, since all stats should now be sent via the CloudWatch
api via the PutMetricData action (ref cfn-push-stats update)

Note that after this change you will need to rebuild your jeos
images to get the new version of cfn-push-stats from heat-jeos

Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5eec60d3dd0abfb32e2b4777635f1b0e2714a2c2

heat templates : Add boto config to HA templates

Add boto config to HA/IHA templates as it's now required for
authenticated cfn-push-stats which uses the CloudWatch API

Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I8670f6774834e9f41870240496fe74728306cf17

commit_message:
heat engine : Move watch logic into WatchRule class

Move engine/manager.py logic into WatchRule class so watch-
related DB manipulation and related logic is encapsulated in
the WatchRule class

Fixes #217

Change-Id: I5405ab631de17efda7eefb45dadad55ee12c533c
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
ReST API: Report template validation errors

Use a different HTTP Status code (Bad Request) for validation errors.

Change-Id: Ie1097dfbbe920a2efb641b343114d7b4decac473
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fixes live_migration missing migrate_data parameter in Hyper-V driver

Fixes Bug #1066513

Live migration on Hyper-V fails due to the parameter "migrate_data" that
has been added to the signature of live_migration(...) in
nova.virt.ComputeDriver.

This fix adds the new parameter.

Change-Id: I393f6706bc144838ae232dfb275460620bc203e2

first to ensure that self.disabled is set to False before we
test for it.

Fixes LP Bug #1064319.

Change-Id: I66d279eb216160c175339aa1750c6868817290d9
'}]
commit_message:
Call setup_s3 before checking for disabled state.

Updates the Glance TestS3 suite so that it calls setup_s3
first to ensure that self.disabled is set to False before we
test for it.

Fixes LP Bug #1064319.

Change-Id: I66d279eb216160c175339aa1750c6868817290d9

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-09 14:11:24.000000000', 'message': "nova-manage doesn't validate key to update the quota

nova-manage doesn't validate the key value supplied to
update the quota, as a result unnecessary records will be
created in db and user will be under the impression that
quota value got updated.
This patch validates the input value given to the key.

fixes bug 1064359
Change-Id: I9928f30881aa2780a23005b5f69aa67a44f314c5
"}]
commit_message:
nova-manage doesn't validate key to update the quota

nova-manage doesn't validate the key value supplied to
update the quota, as a result unnecessary records will be
created in db and user will be under the impression that
quota value got updated.
This patch validates the input value given to the key.

fixes bug 1064359
Change-Id: I9928f30881aa2780a23005b5f69aa67a44f314c5

commit_message:
Adds tenant_id to quantum net-create command

fixes bug 1064897

As in the bug report, there was the tenant-id flag missing from this
command - adding it in makes the command work

Change-Id: Ie8a3e9dfbcdf22785464aec0810a66b042260af4

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-05 12:28:50.000000000', 'message': 'Fix XenServer's ability to boot xen type images

Fixes bug 1055431.

As the scheduler wants to boot a vm_mode=xen type of image, the host's
"supported_instances" capability is used for finding a good candidate.
In the Xapi case, this field was not populated.

This fix modifies the xapi xenhost plugin, so the Xen host capabilities
are returned back to the compute node, as "host_capabilities".
On the compute side, the mentioned information is used, to extract the
"supported_instances" information.

Change-Id: I2da11ab81f74b5b52e2c30832a694470978e21b0
'}]
commit_message:
Fix XenServer's ability to boot xen type images

Fixes bug 1055431.

As the scheduler wants to boot a vm_mode=xen type of image, the host's
"supported_instances" capability is used for finding a good candidate.
In the Xapi case, this field was not populated.

This fix modifies the xapi xenhost plugin, so the Xen host capabilities
are returned back to the compute node, as "host_capabilities".
On the compute side, the mentioned information is used, to extract the
"supported_instances" information.

Change-Id: I2da11ab81f74b5b52e2c30832a694470978e21b0

commit_message:
Fix CloudPipe extension XML serialization

It is completely broken right now and this fixes it to properly
traverse a list of cloudpipe instance dictionaries, resulting
in XML output that matches the API spec.

Fixes bug: 1056242

Change-Id: Ic768afeaa76d776fd55a4f618d14fa41ed4c8a63

[{'created': '2012-10-05 12:19:14.000000000', 'message': "Restore SIGPIPE default action for subprocesses

Python ignores SIGPIPE on startup, because it prefers to check every
write and raise an IOError exception rather than taking the signal. Most
Unix subprocesses don't expect to work this way. This patch (adapted
from Colin Watson's post at http://tinyurl.com/2a7mzh5) sets SIGPIPE
back to the default action for cinder.utils.execute and cinder-rootwrap
created subprocesses.

Fixes bug 1053364

Change-Id: I4b3307bd2f0f5d0da529d8b7d80fabae28c57732
"}]
commit_message:
Restore SIGPIPE default action for subprocesses

Python ignores SIGPIPE on startup, because it prefers to check every
write and raise an IOError exception rather than taking the signal. Most
Unix subprocesses don't expect to work this way. This patch (adapted
from Colin Watson's post at http://tinyurl.com/2a7mzh5) sets SIGPIPE
back to the default action for cinder.utils.execute and cinder-rootwrap
created subprocesses.

Fixes bug 1053364

Change-Id: I4b3307bd2f0f5d0da529d8b7d80fabae28c57732

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-05 12:46:29.000000000', 'message': "ip_protocol for ec2 security groups

fix for bug 1057196.
-Enforce restrictions on IP protocol in AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress call.
 This value may only be: 'tcp', 'udp', 'icmp', '6', '17' or '1'
-Ensure that ip protocol returned from DescribeSecurityGroups is in lower case,
 in case security group was set improperly in previous versions
-Update EC2APIError in nova/exception.py to remove the HTTP error code from the
 message. The HTTP error code is inserted in nova.api.ec2.faults.Fault. Inserting
 the code in the EC2APIError causes the HTTP code to appear twice in the message
-Update unit tests to expect new error message when invalid protocol is entered.
-Fixing pep8 issues

Change-Id: Iffe0f38abde327288e6a3960a72ad6a273f78aca
"}]
commit_message:
ip_protocol for ec2 security groups

fix for bug 1057196.
-Enforce restrictions on IP protocol in AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress call.
 This value may only be: 'tcp', 'udp', 'icmp', '6', '17' or '1'
-Ensure that ip protocol returned from DescribeSecurityGroups is in lower case,
 in case security group was set improperly in previous versions
-Update EC2APIError in nova/exception.py to remove the HTTP error code from the
 message. The HTTP error code is inserted in nova.api.ec2.faults.Fault. Inserting
 the code in the EC2APIError causes the HTTP code to appear twice in the message
-Update unit tests to expect new error message when invalid protocol is entered.
-Fixing pep8 issues

Change-Id: Iffe0f38abde327288e6a3960a72ad6a273f78aca

commit_message:
Fix booting a raw image on XenServer

Fixes bug 1055413.

ImageType.from_string removed, as it was only used by its test.
Introduced ImageType.get_role, that returns the image's role within the
VM. In case of DISK_* image types, the role is always 'root'. Role
should be the key when accessing the vdis dictionary.

Change-Id: Ieb952a9246d06a8280510113a98b888237abcc65

commit_message:
Restore SIGPIPE default action for subprocesses

Python ignores SIGPIPE on startup, because it prefers to check every
write and raise an IOError exception rather than taking the signal. Most
Unix subprocesses don't expect to work this way. This patch (adapted
from Colin Watson's post at http://tinyurl.com/2a7mzh5) sets SIGPIPE
back to the default action for nova.utils.execute and nova-rootwrap
created subprocesses.

Fixes bug 1053364

Change-Id: I17e1629bb4ef4268515c6734ddb6e12746739c52

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-04 20:35:07.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Improve the idempotency of iscsi detach

When detaching an iscsi volume it is possible for the iscsi commands
to run concurrently, causing a target to be deleted by one greenthread
while the other is continuing. When removing the iscsi connection,
we should always ignore exit code 21 because that means that the
target has already been removed.

Fixes bug 1057719

Change-Id: I0c9f2623f85a817e2be506f9a6d523d45c76848a
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Improve the idempotency of iscsi detach

When detaching an iscsi volume it is possible for the iscsi commands
to run concurrently, causing a target to be deleted by one greenthread
while the other is continuing. When removing the iscsi connection,
we should always ignore exit code 21 because that means that the
target has already been removed.

Fixes bug 1057719

Change-Id: I0c9f2623f85a817e2be506f9a6d523d45c76848a

commit_message:
Fix startup with DELETED instances

Make sure that compute manager with DELETED and SOFT_DELETED instances
starts up properly. Before it was possible to end up with only the db
entry and no local configuration allowing a successful restart (even
then it would be the wrong decision to try).

Fixes bug 1053441

Change-Id: Iab1ca81068733a5e8546c32ad122f1d60d22310b

commit_message:
Pass block_device_info to destroy in revert_resize

Fixes bug #1056285

Passing block_device_info allows the driver to clean up block
device mappings (detaching) properly on the newly resized instance

Change-Id: I2527f883883c741dbf4d20be0ca33dbef6f9f36a
(cherry picked from commit a9fc0c43873ef7dfe3c2ee0e57b219ddd6746df3)

commit_message:
Restore SIGPIPE default action for subprocesses

Python ignores SIGPIPE on startup, because it prefers to check every
write and raise an IOError exception rather than taking the signal. Most
Unix subprocesses don't expect to work this way. This patch (adapted
from Colin Watson's post at http://tinyurl.com/2a7mzh5) sets SIGPIPE
back to the default action for quantum.agent.linux.utils.execute,
quantum.common.utils.execute and quantum-rootwrap created subprocesses.

Fixes bug 1053364

Change-Id: Ib805f1f8846c245b75a5ea64278c840b823c1fb2

messages:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-10 15:02:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/14286/2/check/gate-horizon-merge/1484 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/14286/2/check/gate-horizon-selenium/382 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14286/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/14118 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14286/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-cinder/4097 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-10-11 19:45:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-10-11 19:57:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Do not merge

(1 inline comment)

The logic here isn't quite right. What we're trying to prevent is an admin locking themselves out, which means it's not about having *any role* on the admin project that matters, it's that the user must have the *admin* role on *at least one project*.

So the logic needs to be reworked such that if the user is removing the "admin" from themselves, we need to check and see if they have the admin role anywhere else, preventing them from the removal if they don't.

Otherwise an admin is free to remove any other roles from any other users/projects that they like.'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-10-12 14:12:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-10-12 14:17:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-10-12 14:24:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Gabriel,

I've discovered a possible bug in the admin dashboard. After digging a bit more in roles and projects, I've found that, assuming you have 2 project with admin roles, if you delete the 'admin' role on the 'current' project, the default project changes automatically to the second one, but still under the 'Project' tab you see your 'Current project' as the first one, while you actually operate on the second... That's the reason I've modified the check to perform validation if you remove the 'admin' role on the 'current' project, and to disallow this. This will force the user to switch first to another project so that to remove the 'admin' role from the chosen one, thus making it impossible to switch back to the 'disabled' project. Actually this scenario covers the described defect... 
If you still wish to check for 'admin' role on 'ALL' projects - keystone now doesn't support loading of all user roles across all projects (tenant_id is required), then it should be a bigger change, which should also fix the defect described above.."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-12 14:50:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build successful

'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-10-12 22:46:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'created': '2012-10-10 14:39:35.000000000', 'message': "User shouldn't remove their own roles on project

own permissions on the current(admin) project. This

Change-Id: I1e60a11d628d6490ad24a8149b43ac307afb4780
"}, {'created': '2012-10-12 14:12:45.000000000', 'message': "User shouldn't remove their own roles on project

Added a check if the user is trying to delete their
own 'admin' role on the current project. This is added
to prevent the users from locking their own
access to Dashboard. Also, if the 'admin' role on the
current project is removed, Dashboard automatically

commit_message:
User shouldn't remove their own roles on project

Added a check if the user is trying to delete their
own 'admin' role on the current project. This is added
to prevent the users from locking their own
access to Dashboard. Also, if the 'admin' role on the
current project is removed, Dashboard automatically
switches to another project for which the user has 'admin'
role, but the previous project still is displayed as current.

Fixes bug 1046538

Also improved the unit test scenarios a bit.

Change-Id: I1e60a11d628d6490ad24a8149b43ac307afb4780

commit_message:
fix unittest create_subnet_with_none_gateway_fully_allocated

Create subnet with none gateway and fully allocated should return
status code 409:
$ quantum subnet-create net1 --allocation-pool start=10.0.0.1,end=10.0.0.254 \
10.0.0.0/24
Found overlapping allocation pools:{u'start': u'10.0.0.1',
u'end': u'10.0.0.254'} 10.0.0.1 for subnet 10.0.0.0/24.

So change unittest 'create_subnet_with_none_gateway_fully_allocated' to
create_subnet_with_none_gateway_fully_allocated_returns_409

Change-Id: I28e6ad812602d503ec7bc520b1aa29fa033bb3e9

messages:
[{'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-09-26 16:05:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Did this fail because the db took too long to come up and it was out of retries or because checking for the db so often overloaded the system somehow?

If it's the former then couldn't we just up the retries? Either way I'm not sure it's clear what the problem is."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-09-26 16:22:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-09-26 16:30:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The former. I.E. the DB didn't start within the 10s.
We could up the retries, but I changed to match nova."}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2012-10-03 22:40:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-10-08 14:57:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-10-09 17:12:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Could this change make the service unusable for ~10 seconds under normal conditions on startup? Why don't we do a backoff that starts at 1 second and expands up to 10+ seconds?"}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2012-10-09 17:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

I think it will be a good idea to have something like exponential backoff but if we could do it separately from this prop, it would be great. 

Although, its necessary to check if this affects the service.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-10-09 22:49:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

yes exponential backoff is the standard way to handle this.

Though the config vars sql_max_retries and sql_retry_interval suggest the existing implementation.

I suppose I could leave the interval at 1s,
and up sql_max_retries to 60.
That would solve most cases,
while not having the latency issue.
I'll do that in a new revision...

If doing exponential backoff it would be more invasive,
as you'd probably need to implement that in other
projects' services too for consistency, with a
new config var sql_connect_timeout and deprecate
the two aforementioned config vars."}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-10-09 22:56:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-09 23:16:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

[{'created': '2012-09-26 15:53:53.000000000', 'message': "check for database every 10s on startup

Previously the check was done every second,
which left a window of 10s where the database
needed to become available.
This was seen to fail when booting a heavily loaded system.
This change also aligns with what's done in nova.

Fixes bug: 1056976
Change-Id: I9c1ca9ff97a79a96d2a8230ed1aa08c17ae4b8fa
"}, {'created': '2012-10-09 22:56:53.000000000', 'message': 'change the default sql connection timeout to 60s

commit_message:
change the default sql connection timeout to 60s

Previously the check was done only for 10s.
This was seen to fail when booting a heavily loaded system.
This change also aligns more closely with
the larger timeout used in nova.

Fixes bug: 1056976
Change-Id: I9c1ca9ff97a79a96d2a8230ed1aa08c17ae4b8fa

commit_message:
Display acceptable disk/container formats in help text

Fixes bug #1056497

This patch provides more information in the help text. Originally the text
provided the trivial definitions of the arguments disk_format and
container_format. This patch updates the text to display the acceptable
formats.

Change-Id: I893b52c9f72a34c75e8bea522820863592300302
