revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-08 14:49:08.000000000', 'message': 'Add insecure option to registry https client

This fixes LP bug #1063793.

This adds a new API config option registry_client_insecure
(default false) which optionally allows not to specify a ca
file for registry connections from the API server.
The default is false so existing behaviour is
unchanged unless this option is specified.
Adding this option makes the registry symmetric wrt the API
with which you can connect using clients with --insecure

Change-Id: I4fa462cd68afaf14f7d7de6c572980a41c0849d6
'}, {'created': '2012-10-09 12:06:10.000000000', 'message': 'Add insecure option to registry https client

This fixes LP bug #1063793.

This adds a new API config option registry_client_insecure
(default false) which optionally allows not to specify a ca
file for registry connections from the API server.
The default is false so existing behaviour is
unchanged unless this option is specified.
Adding this option makes the registry symmetric wrt the API
with which you can connect using clients with --insecure

Change-Id: I4fa462cd68afaf14f7d7de6c572980a41c0849d6
'}]
commit_message:
Add insecure option to registry https client

This fixes LP bug #1063793.

This adds a new API config option registry_client_insecure
(default false) which optionally allows not to specify a ca
file for registry connections from the API server.
The default is false so existing behaviour is
unchanged unless this option is specified.
Adding this option makes the registry symmetric wrt the API
with which you can connect using clients with --insecure

Change-Id: I4fa462cd68afaf14f7d7de6c572980a41c0849d6

I think I understand it why, but I want to make sure everybody is on the same page. Can you explain why this fix isn't going to cause regression on bug 1045824?"}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2012-10-09 16:03:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Brian,

Yeah, you're right to double check that this change won't affect other corner cases. 

I tried to test as much as I could ... the matrix of tests I was running was:

echo hi | glance  --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-create --disk-format raw --container-format bare

if [ $? -ne 0 ]
then
  echo fail
  exit 1
fi

cat /etc/motd |  glance  --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-create --disk-format raw --container-format bare

if [ $? -ne 0 ]
then
  echo fail
  exit 1
fi

glance  --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-create --disk-format raw --container-format bare < /etc/motd

if [ $? -ne 0 ]
then
  echo fail
  exit 1
fi

glance  --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-create --disk-format raw --container-format bare --file /etc/motd

if [ $? -ne 0 ]
then
  echo fail
  exit 1
fi

touch /tmp/empty.$$
cat /tmp/empty.$$ | glance  --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-create --disk-format raw --container-format bare

if [ $? -ne 0 ]
then
  echo fail
  exit 1
fi

glance  --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-create --disk-format raw --container-format bare --file /tmp/empty.$$

if [ $? -ne 0 ]
then
  echo fail
  exit 1
fi

rm /tmp/empty.$$


(* part A)
id=`glance  --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-create --disk-format raw --container-format bare | grep '^| id' | awk '{print $4}'`

(* part B)
glance --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-update $id < /etc/motd

if [ $? -ne 0 ]
then
  echo fail
  exit 1
fi

id=`glance  --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-create --disk-format raw --container-format bare | grep '^| id' | awk '{print $4}'`


echo hi | glance --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-update $id

if [ $? -ne 0 ]
then
  echo fail
  exit 1
fi

glance --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-update $id --property xxx=yyy
if [ $? -ne 0 ]
then
  echo fail
  exit 1
fi


echo !!FIFO create!!

mkfifo /tmp/fifo.$$

glance  --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-create --disk-format raw --container-format bare < /tmp/fifo.$$ > /tmp/out.$$ &

echo hi > /tmp/fifo.$$

wait

cat /tmp/out.$$
rm /tmp/out.$$

rm /tmp/fifo.$$


echo !!FIFO update!!
id=`glance  --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-create --disk-format raw --container-format bare | grep '^| id' | awk '{print $4}'`

if [ $? -ne 0 ]
then
  echo fail
  exit 1
fi

mkfifo /tmp/fifo.$$

glance  --os-image-url https://localhost:9292  --os-auth-token $TOKEN -d -v  --insecure image-update $id < /tmp/fifo.$$ > /tmp/out.$$ &

echo hi > /tmp/fifo.$$

wait

cat /tmp/out.$$



As far as I can tell one of these tests (marked '*') is equivalent to the case in that bug.

I'm not sure of the best way to go about it, but I think that there is some room for more functional tests such as these as part of the review/gating jobs. (I don't know if they would live in the python-glanceclient code or glance or tempest...)"}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2012-10-09 16:11:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Can you explain why this fix isn't going to cause regression on bug 1045824?

I never answered your question, sorry. The 'update' will use PUT so 'transfer-encoding: chunked' will be enabled, so the absence of a content-length header makes sense."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-10-09 17:22:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Handle create/update of images with unknown size

It may not be possible to know in advance the total
size of image data which is to be uploaded, for example
if the data is being piped to stdin.

To handle this we use HTTP Transfer-Encoding: chunked
and do not set any image size headers.

Various subtly different cases needed to be handled for
both image-create and image-update, including:

 * input from named pipe
 * piped input of zero size
 * regular file of zero length

Fix for bug 1056220.

Change-Id: I0c7f0a64d883e058993b954a1c465c5b057f2bcf

commit_message:
Implement blueprint ssl-connect-rework

Use pyOpenSSL for HTTPS connections.

This allows:

* Neater loading of system CA files
* Optional disabling of SSL compression

The performance gain from disabling SSL compression is significant
in cases where the image being uploaded/downloaded is in an already
compressed format (eg qcow2).

Related to bp ssl-connect-rework.

Change-Id: I0568b6c95c5fc7b8eafdbd0284e24c453660a55a

commit_message:
Stops compute api import at import time

There is an automatic import of compute.api at import time
whenever anything under compute is imported. This leads to all
sorts of weird dependency problems such as the one here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14170/

This modifies the import to happen when compute.API() is called,
which is how we handle it for network and volume. A few imports
were also modified to make it consistent with this new style.

Change-Id: Ic748376510aa4cc48dfefc6ec36621d0ae498bfc

commit_message:
Fix imports in openstack compute tests

This makes imports in a number of tests consistent. There were also
various places where files were being stubbed out that werent explicitly
imported. This patch fixes those as well. It also moves compute api
stubbing to stub the actual compute.api.API class instead of
compute.API. Includes a rewrite of test_createserverext to stub the
create method instead of doing a bunch of odd setup with a mock
compute api.

Change-Id: Id8ebb2f65228fafeac69c7ab635ff8909b79c449

commit_message:
Pass correct task_state on snapshot

This fixes an issue where we were not passing the correct task_state to
the compute manager thereby triggering an 'unexpected task-state error'
when the snapshot finished.

This error only manifested itself in multi-cell setups where the
compute-manager and compute-api are using separate DB's and therefore
must rely on the RPC-layer to enforce consistency.

Fixes bug 1065250

Change-Id: Ie07454f0d2075f5c3f2dd53b4e5ff9983ea3241f

[{'created': '2012-10-11 21:08:16.000000000', 'message': "Honor sample_rate in StatsD logging.

It's there to let administrators turn down the barrage of stats data
that StatsD must cope with, but it wasn't actually honored. Worse, if
the sample rate was set to e.g. 0.2, the stats would all be multiplied
by its inverse, e.g. 2. This patch actually drops packets when
sample_rate < 1.

Fortunately, the default sample rate is 1 (i.e. drop nothing), and
multiplying by 1/1 doesn't change anything, so stats with the default
sample rate of 1.0 are, and have been, just fine.

Fixes bug 1065643.

Change-Id: I66663144009ae4c9ee96f6a111745d8f5d2f5ca3

commit_message:
Honor sample_rate in StatsD logging.

It's there to let administrators turn down the barrage of stats data
that StatsD must cope with, but it wasn't actually honored. Worse, if
the sample rate was set to e.g. 0.2, the stats would all be multiplied
by its inverse, e.g. 2. This patch actually drops packets when
sample_rate < 1, so you get correct measurements.

Fortunately, the default sample rate is 1 (i.e. drop nothing), and
multiplying by 1/1 doesn't change anything, so stats with the default
sample rate of 1.0 are, and have been, just fine.

Fixes bug 1065643.

Also, make the two touched files compliant with pep8 v1.3.3.

Change-Id: I66663144009ae4c9ee96f6a111745d8f5d2f5ca3

commit_message:
Dis-associate an auto-assigned floating IP should return proper warning

Added new exception class CannotDissociateAutoAssignedFloatingIP and raised
exception instead of return.

Fixes bug 1061499

Change-Id: I348573a235c6b81653837267072b5c48fa15b8af

In general this looks really good.

However, in my test I didn't find that E128 requires that there be one argument per line in multiline argument lists. I would prefer instances of

    some_long_foo(arg1, arg2,
            arg3)


to be fixed like


    some_long_foo(arg1, arg2,
                            arg3)


rather than

    some_long_foo(arg1,
                            arg2,
                            arg3)

But I suppose it is just a personal preference, and I think the guideline in HACKING may contradict me."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-09-24 16:20:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

fixed_ip_get_by_instance use instance uuid not id, so change to
uuid in remove-fixed-ip.

Change-Id: Ic7526c7e91933424c04be9bb91d4a98cfedd9b01
'}]
commit_message:
Used instance uuid rather than id in remove-fixed-ip

remove-fixed-ip called db method fixed_ip_get_by_instance. but
fixed_ip_get_by_instance use instance uuid not id, so change to
uuid in remove-fixed-ip.

Fixed bug: #1065899

Change-Id: Ic7526c7e91933424c04be9bb91d4a98cfedd9b01

commit_message:
Migrate DHCP host info during resize

Update instance host to migration_ref['dest_compute'] before
update_dhcp to make its DHCP host info will be written in dhcp-hostsfile.

Make similiar change in finish_revert_resize.

Fixes bug 1065440

Change-Id: I9d3e0ebf8512f98f2943999e7ad95bc58f2bf585

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-11 17:13:45.000000000', 'message': 'Make run_tests.sh fail if no tests are actually run

Right now, run_tests seems to report test success if there is a
catastrophic failure early in the process. This can happen if you
have a python file that fails to parse, or if something else in
the test environment setup fails to initialize (such as creating
the empty database for the test run). Nosetests will report
success, but indicate that zero tests were run.

This patch snatches the output of nosetests and, if zero tests
ran, reports to the user that something is broken and offers a few
suggestions.

Change-Id: Ide6fd8b212f0650cb227f60b25d4b4e62ee150ac
'}, {'created': '2012-10-12 14:11:12.000000000', 'message': 'Make run_tests.sh fail if no tests are actually run

Right now, run_tests seems to report test success if there is a
catastrophic failure early in the process. This can happen if you
have a python file that fails to parse, or if something else in
the test environment setup fails to initialize (such as creating
the empty database for the test run). Nosetests will report
success, but indicate that zero tests were run.

This patch snatches the output of nosetests and, if zero tests
ran, reports to the user that something is broken and offers a few
suggestions.

Change-Id: Ide6fd8b212f0650cb227f60b25d4b4e62ee150ac
'}]
commit_message:
Make run_tests.sh fail if no tests are actually run

Right now, run_tests seems to report test success if there is a
catastrophic failure early in the process. This can happen if you
have a python file that fails to parse, or if something else in
the test environment setup fails to initialize (such as creating
the empty database for the test run). Nosetests will report
success, but indicate that zero tests were run.

This patch snatches the output of nosetests and, if zero tests
ran, reports to the user that something is broken and offers a few
suggestions.

Change-Id: Ide6fd8b212f0650cb227f60b25d4b4e62ee150ac

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-12 02:04:14.000000000', 'message': "read_deleted snapshot and volume id mappings.

Since the migration that creates the volume_id_mappings and
snapshot_id_mappings tables does not populate the 'deleted' column,
queries to this table should not limit results to 'deleted=0'.
Limiting to non-deleted rows results in duplicate mappings being
created for existing instance mappings after an upgrade, and
throws off volume and snapshot ID to UUID mapping.

This is a stop-gap measure to ensure avoid serious breakage during
an upgrade.  The NULL columns in this table are actually unused
currently and can be populated in later grizzly migrations, if they
end up being used.

Fixes bug 1065785.

Change-Id: I893c994362a203288b9984f0ede24cbb274bfcc5
"}]
commit_message:
read_deleted snapshot and volume id mappings.

Since the migration that creates the volume_id_mappings and
snapshot_id_mappings tables does not populate the 'deleted' column,
queries to this table should not limit results to 'deleted=0'.
Limiting to non-deleted rows results in duplicate mappings being
created for existing instance mappings after an upgrade, and
throws off volume and snapshot ID to UUID mapping.

This is a stop-gap measure to ensure avoid serious breakage during
an upgrade.  The NULL columns in this table are actually unused
currently and can be populated in later grizzly migrations, if they
end up being used.

Fixes bug 1065785.

Change-Id: I893c994362a203288b9984f0ede24cbb274bfcc5

commit_message:
heat engine : Move watch logic into WatchRule class

Move engine/manager.py logic into WatchRule class so watch-
related DB manipulation and related logic is encapsulated in
the WatchRule class

Fixes #217

Change-Id: I21f698f623413bf2752ff70ee47008a2ffc4ed56
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-12 18:07:36.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Add support for finer-grained policy decisions"

This reverts commit 3fc46892

After a productive discussion here:

  http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-October/thread.html#1566

It appears that we don't yet have a really compelling use 
case for this and folks are worried about the extra 
complexity it brings. I think it's safe to say there's a
consensus that we shouldn't proceed with this idea yet. We 
can always revisit this again later if needs be.'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Add support for finer-grained policy decisions"

This reverts commit 3fc46892

After a productive discussion here:

  http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-October/thread.html#1566

It appears that we don't yet have a really compelling use 
case for this and folks are worried about the extra 
complexity it brings. I think it's safe to say there's a
consensus that we shouldn't proceed with this idea yet. We 
can always revisit this again later if needs be.

commit_message:
heat : db API add watch_rule_get_by_name

Add watch_rule_get_by_name, and move the previous
watch_rule_get to look up rule by ID, which is consistent
with the other api calls.  Lookup by id is required for
WatchRule rework

Ref #217

Change-Id: I4b5d08ffcd31b6b522c65edd0a202e8cf5a367b8
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Implement snapshots for raw backend

blueprint snapshots-for-everyone

Use simple qemu-img convert for raw snapshots.
Polymorphically select snapshot behavior for
raw and qcow2.
Allow images to be constructed from actual device/file path.

Change-Id: I6a57e43c6775c144c41a53382dcc7504ce6d4c43

commit_message:
Avoid RPC calls while holding iptables lock.

This exhibitied itself as very slow instance starts on a Canonical
test cluster. This was because do_referesh_security_group_rules()
was making rpc calls while holding the iptables lock. This refactor
avoids that while making no functional changes (I hope).

Fixes bug: 1062314

commit_message:
Tempest tests to cover live-block-migration

Related to bug 1051881.

Two test cases: one to cover the live block migration on XenServer, and
the other to indicate that the machine status is left in an inconsistent
state in case a non-existing host is specified as target.
To run the live-migration tests with block migration, include:

    [compute]
    live_migration_available = true
    use_block_migration_for_live_migration = true

in your tempest.conf

To run these tests, the hypervisors must support the Storage XenMotion
feature.

Change-Id: I1e6cc903fa573ecd219a08bf4dddd9cc1f4f60df

commit_message:
Fixes JavaScript count bug in tables.

When showing tables, and you had the summary, "No items to display",
the counter at table footer said Displaying 1 items. This commit fixes
this counting issue.
Affected sub-pages: Instances, Volumes, Images & Snapshots, etc.

Change-Id: I61e3714a45e6553cab2cb8a8100e2b9729735a83

commit_message:
Open 2012.1.4 development

Bump version to 2012.1.4 to formally open development after the release
of 2012.1.3.

See http://wiki.openstack.org/StableBranchRelease

Note - 2012.1.3 is expected to be the final official release of Essex.

Change-Id: I0de6fae1495deab60bd667e4653210b22b994b39

Bump version to 2012.1.4

commit_message:
Add support for v4-fixed-ip when using quantum

This patch fixes backward-compatibility of the v4-fixed-ip nic
parameter with Quantum networking. While a fixed ip can be
configured by creating a port and passing the port-id in the nic
parameter, the existing v4-fixed-ip property wasn't implemented.

Fixes bug 1046358

Change-Id: I4edeab426772e03cdcd55cb1d3d5b48d9cc99640

commit_message:
Display error message when invalid instance-id is given

For euca-describe-instances even if invalid instance_id is given
no error message was displayed, handled this by displaying
a proper error message, so that the user will know the status
of both valid and invalid instance's.

Fixes bug 1050225

Change-Id: I0fc1671007745ed55fa42c6929de5f4478389e23

subject: Add NoopQuotaDriver
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-10-04 16:23:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I have some doubts about this; I'm worried that overriding some of the get_*() methods in this way may break things.  There's also a possibility that returning None from the reserve() method may cause some problems.

I'm guessing that the problems I foresee may not be an issue in cells, since they don't typically run nova-api, but I could also see someone wanting to use this driver because they aren't concerned about quota checking, and it could cause problems for them.  Can we confirm that this doesn't break anything for that case?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-04 16:37:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

commit_message:
Add NoopQuotaDriver

Can be used to disable quota checking in child cells by specifying:

quota_driver=nova.quota.NoopQuotaDriver

Change-Id: I19d1ad5d18cae73a7c5acc621a84bf91f585c1e7

[{'created': '2012-10-09 22:24:07.000000000', 'message': "Add test for v1 image visibility

These tests just characterize the existing behavior in order to protect
us from unintentional changes. To support the tests, the
FakeAuthMiddleware was changed to take a tenant 'none' to mean the
context should have tenant = None.

Change-Id: I4f0d771a6c45dedc7b1a0d2a735dbf4fb8cc1322
"}]
commit_message:
Add test for v1 image visibility

These tests just characterize the existing behavior in order to protect
us from unintentional changes. To support the tests, the
FakeAuthMiddleware was changed to take a tenant 'none' to mean the
context should have tenant = None.

Change-Id: I4f0d771a6c45dedc7b1a0d2a735dbf4fb8cc1322

The FakeAuthMiddleware was defaulting to admin=True for request
contexts. This creates a situation where it is impossible to test
non-admin requests in some situations.

Change-Id: I949f708efed9f07a43b8506870c5b38fce4b3752

commit_message:
FakeAuth not always admin

The FakeAuthMiddleware was defaulting to admin=True for request
contexts. This creates a situation where it is impossible to test
non-admin requests in some situations.

Change-Id: I949f708efed9f07a43b8506870c5b38fce4b3752

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-11 19:34:49.000000000', 'message': 'Clean up imports in test_servers

There were a lot of assumed imports in test_servers that were not
explicitly being imported. This makes sure all of the used files
are actually imported and makes the importing of all of the files
consistent.

Change-Id: I07d20c44de7a350465dce91fbbe5ac9fd2426d37
'}]
commit_message:
Clean up imports in test_servers

There were a lot of assumed imports in test_servers that were not
explicitly being imported. This makes sure all of the used files
are actually imported and makes the importing of all of the files
consistent.

Change-Id: I07d20c44de7a350465dce91fbbe5ac9fd2426d37

"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-10-11 08:57:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

So now the "read" self.instance_rules() is run outside the lock, while the "write" functions are inside the lock.
Also we now take the lock per instance rather than for all instances.

This seems correct to me.

BTW, Why is external=True on this lock?
I can see why external=True is required for apply() in the manager, but are we protecting anything outside the process here?'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-10-11 09:00:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Good spot - the change looks good to me in terms of no fucntional change.

Not in the scope of this change, but I wonder if it would be possible to add a debug check at the RPC layer to trap on calls being made whilst holding a lock ?'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-10-11 09:06:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@padraig -- I'm not sure why the lock is external. I think it bears looking at, but I'd rather do that later as this bug is hurting my users in production.

@phil -- I have code to do that, but it requires a hilarious amount of pre-work. I'm moving the locking to common (where the RPC code is) and then will implement that."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-10-11 09:07:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-10-11 09:10:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

The lock has to be external because IPtables updates are made by both the network_manager and the compute_manager - and in some cases there are external proceses that also need to make iptables updates (such as settign up basic host UFW rules), and as Nova does a "lets sabe and rebuild the whole thing" we need soneway to sync accross multiple processes/'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-10-11 09:24:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@padraig

>So now the "read" self.instance_rules() is run outside the lock, while the "write" functions are inside the lock. 

Just to be clear I don't think the read of the iptables is outside the lock  (at least I hope not, that wouldn't be right) - but the logic that calculates what the new rules needs to be is, which includes the rpc call, is outside the lock.

>Also we now take the lock per instance rather than for all instances.

The lock itself hasn't changes - it's still on iptables as a whole (as it needs to be to stay consistent with the other uses) - but there is a change of Folsom that made the updates per instance rather than for all instances on each affected host'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-11 09:27:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/14326/1/check/gate-nova-merge/9936 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14326/1/check/gate-nova-docs/5691 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/14326/1/check/gate-nova-python26/7146 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14326/1/check/gate-nova-python27/7211 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14326/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/14270 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14326/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-cinder/4249 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/14326/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/1561 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-10-11 09:47:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Phil.

Yes the "read" is reading state unaffected by the "write". Thanks for the clarification.

Re the lock being held now only per instance,
I was referring to the lock now being inside the
for loop in do_refresh_security_group_rules()
rather an being outside.

Re the external lock. I see why it's required in
apply() in the manager, and that should protect
all external accesses to iptables. But in this
case it seems internal only. Anyway I'm not sure
so we can look at this later.  In general synchronization
calls should get lots of comments as they're by
definition non local in scope.

@Michael

I guess this appropriate for backporting to folsom.
For essex though, it's a performance issue so may
not be appropriate at this stage?

I'll approve this change in a while after giving
others a chance to comment.

thanks.'}, {'account_id': 1882, 'date': '2012-10-11 12:02:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-10-11 12:24:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Nice work.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-11 12:24:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.
https://jenkins.openstack.org/zuul/status'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-11 12:44:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/14326/1/gate/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-cinder/4251 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-11 12:44:26.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-10-11 17:02:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

padraig: multiple workers mess with iptables, so anything that is actually calling out needs to be external. I don't think the internal uses of the iptables class needs an external lock though, it should just be the apply method iirc."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-10-11 17:30:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@vish:  Can you clarify what you mean by internal users in this context ?   I was thinkign that if anything is working with the internal representation of the iptables, and is relying on that not changing before it pushes changes back, then all of that needs to occur in the context of the lock.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-10-11 20:49:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

phil: That is correct. But that representation is not shared across processes. I suppose if we want to make sure we avoid races, then anything that needs to make changes depending on the existing state would have to be in the context of an external lock as well.'}]

[{'created': '2012-10-11 04:51:47.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid RPC calls while holding iptables lock.

This exhibitied itself as very slow instance starts on a Canonical
test cluster. This was because do_referesh_security_group_rules()
was making rpc calls while holding the iptables lock. This refactor
avoids that while making no functional changes (I hope).

This should resolve bug 1062314.

Change-Id: I36f805bd72f7bd06082cfe96c58d637203bcffb7
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid RPC calls while holding iptables lock.

This exhibitied itself as very slow instance starts on a Canonical
test cluster. This was because do_referesh_security_group_rules()
was making rpc calls while holding the iptables lock. This refactor
avoids that while making no functional changes (I hope).

This should resolve bug 1062314.

Change-Id: I36f805bd72f7bd06082cfe96c58d637203bcffb7

commit_message:
Splits OpenStack Dashboard bits from framework app code.

Moves everything OpenStack-specific (dashboards, apis, etc.)
into the openstack_dashboard project, achieving a much
cleaner separation between the project-specific code and
the generic Horizon framework code.

Change-Id: I7235b41d449b26c980668fc3eb4360b24508717b

The 1xx codes are "technical" codes used for continuations mostly. I don't think it's possible to see them in results ever, unless something in the stuck is badly broken.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-10-11 17:54:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Darrell, we don't ever want metadata retrieved if the status of the response isn't in the 200 family.  The user of internal client can pass in whatever he wants in the acceptable status list.

The use case I'm using the internal client for right now is ok with 404's on containers if the get_metadata method just returns an empty dict.  Essentially, I'm looking up a flag on a container and if the container doesn't exist or the flag isn't set, my thing won't do it's thing."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-11 18:46:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
fixed internal client things

_get_metadata() should only look for metadata on 200 family http status codes

in the path_parts() in the internal client test file should return distinct unicode strings
with spaces for account, container, and obj

Change-Id: I74e335d3b73a59092a0eec06539f4931420061dd

commit_message:
Bug fixes for install, volume, Folsom updates.

fix bug 1038347 Volume API docs need update after 'guess device' changes
fix bug 1054459 Update glance configuration files and option references for Folsom
fix bug 1064745 Mention the need to install Ubuntu's Cloud Archive keyring
fix bug 1064751 trunk/folsom docs should mention folsom version numbers
fix bug 1064752 nova.conf example refers to wrong IP range
fix bug 1065100 Folsom docs do not install novnc

Change-Id: If7f25d10997e7a8f3641d691a51eef3cf335f96f

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-09 21:17:21.000000000', 'message': 'Tell SQLite to enforce foreign keys.

Fixes bug 1021023.

This requires SQLite version 3.6.19 or greater.  Older versions of
SQLite have no support for enforcing foreign keys.  However, SQLite
ignores unknown PRAGMA commands rather than treating them as errors,
so this change should be harmless with old versions of SQLite.

SQLAlchemy events require SQLAlchemy 0.7 or greater.  But other code
in this module already uses events, so this change should impose no
new SQLAlchemy version requirements.

Change-Id: Ic3eeeddbe012af65fe18c884674699cf16725d8d
'}]
commit_message:
Tell SQLite to enforce foreign keys.

Fixes bug 1021023.

This requires SQLite version 3.6.19 or greater.  Older versions of
SQLite have no support for enforcing foreign keys.  However, SQLite
ignores unknown PRAGMA commands rather than treating them as errors,
so this change should be harmless with old versions of SQLite.

SQLAlchemy events require SQLAlchemy 0.7 or greater.  But other code
in this module already uses events, so this change should impose no
new SQLAlchemy version requirements.

Change-Id: Ic3eeeddbe012af65fe18c884674699cf16725d8d

commit_message:
Remove python 2.5 compat code.

OpenStack does not support python 2.5 anymore.
Only python 2.6 and 2.7 are supported

Change-Id: I19a4629826d529bda94beb8c39a7e0a66e26bca4

commit_message:
Allows removal of ACLs

fixes bug 1049017

As per the bug report, the -remove- form of deletion only works with
 meta headers and not with x-container-read and x-container-write.

This patch by Yukihiro KAWADA detects the container acls and sends
them through to the backend empty like the other metadata values.

patch2 extends metadata-helper in ContainerController tests so that
the new functionality can be tested.

patch3 changes the k.lower().startswith() commands for read/write to
a single k.lower - thanks David :)

patch4 fixes PEP8

patch5 fixes more than two hundred pep8 errors. Except one,
 where the pep8 tool complains of overindent, or underindent
depending on the position on the line. No idea how to fix that one.

patch6 fixes the remaining pep8 error - thanks Darrell

Change-Id: I36c2dd72b4636136c5ce7db414bf2b61501090ad

commit_message:
deallocate_fixed_ip attempts to update deleted ip

Fixes bug 1017633. When deleting a vm, the nova
network manager looks to deallocate wrong fixed
ip when context has read_deleted set to 'yes',
in case when a network had been deleted and re-
created , it attempts to update already deleted
fixed_ips and therefore looks to teardown from
wrong network_id as well.

Change-Id: I574a20273220ef81498403da80f489732ae81eb1
(cherry picked from commit 61ab72d15b3ac61b245e0bdd4a7bee5f3a673f75)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-09-26 16:15:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This one makes me a little nervous because we're changing the behaviour of a function used in lots of places and read_deleted seems to be a constant source of subtle bugs.

Given that we're passing read_deleted='yes' now, I'd have expected at least one caller would have needed to set read_deleted='yes' on the context

That said, I'm not seeing any caller that obviously needs read_deleted='yes'

Vish - thoughts? I'd like to be pretty conservative at this point on stable/essex"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-09-26 16:19:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-09-26 19:33:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The reason for proposing this is that it is needed for the dependent patch to go in:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/13678/

Which keeps getting reported:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1053825
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1053828'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-11 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-11 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-10-11 12:48:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sorry I took so long getting back to this

Looking at Rick Harris's commit c40ee5cfe which introduced the read_deleted='yes' here it's pretty hard to see any logic to why read_deleted='yes' was used for a bunch of fixed IP operations

I went through all callers of fixed_ip_get_by_address() and I see lots of cases where deleted fixed IPs could cause weirdness like the bugs described and no cases where we really want to operate on deleted fixed IPs

While deleting and re-creating networks doesn't sound like something you'd do a lot, the behaviour seems obscurely broken enough that it's worth fixing.

The function is called in so many places that this is a risky change, but I'm fairly well assured now that it should be safe. Also, it has been on master for almost 6 months.

Vish - please re-open"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-10-11 16:16:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Restored

commit_message:
fixed_ip_get_by_address read_deleted from context

Fixes bug 996482. by default fixed_ip_get_by_address
always sets read_deleted='yes'.  Changed it to accept
read_deleted value from context.
updated .mailmap to rewrite my old email to new email

Change-Id: If94251972df7bbcfdeebc226613edac0a3f41186
(cherry picked from commit c1e54e1968faa23dfa26796fdb8f3f8d9ba79367)
